summary: When Bran hears Sansa’s letter asking them all to bend the knee and points out she lost her wolf, I always thought it was a sad...
body:
When Bran hears Sansa’s letter asking them all to bend the knee and points out she lost her wolf, I always thought it was a sad statement. Like, she has no protection anymore.

But fandom would always tell me it meant she wasn’t a Stark anymore. That seems strange to me since this generation of Stark kids are the only Stark kids who have had wolves.

I was also very upset by the chapters where she dreams of lady. And then to learn about the various “deaths” wargs experience. Like the true death is when your body and all the creatures you warged into are dead.

So that means… Sansa experienced a death when Lady died. Not just a traumatic incident of losing a pet, but something inside herself. Varamyr Sixskins was laid low (and seems to go mad?) because of the death of his Eagle. Much of that trauma seems to be that he was actually inside the Eagle when Melisandre blew it up or whatever.

But if Summer can sense that Lady died, then Sansa must’ve felt it even more keenly. I wouldn’t have blamed her if she went insane.

(Anyway, unrelated, one of the reasons I think the show’s depiction of Summer’s death is bullshit is because Bran seems just fine after. But also they clearly want to save money on the wolf CGI. Not that the wolves CAN’T die, just that it would be a bigger deal if they did.)

summary: Why would Jon (Rhaegar's bastard who had vowed to wear no crown) or Sansa (a woman who got married with a southern dwarf) be...
question: Why would Jon (Rhaegar's bastard who had vowed to wear no crown) or Sansa (a woman who got married with a southern dwarf) be accepted as king or queen of North while Bran is still alive ? [Books]
answer:
First, Jon will probably be named KitN before the parentage reveal (as it was in the show), but more than likely it will be due to Robb’s will (which is still floating around there). This will probably happen long before Bran actually pops back up south of the wall (if he ever does). After the parentage reveal, there could be circumstances that lead to North still accepting him, especially since he was raised by Ned Stark and will have been their king and proven himself for a minute.

Sansa’s marriage means nothing in regards to the North accepting her given that a) it was forced on her by the king they were rebelling against and b) she can get the marriage annulled, especially given that the lack of consummation is well known (IIRC). It’s highly doubtful that in the books the marriage will be thrown in her face by someone in the North. D&D fucked up when it came to a lot of the Northern characterization and with female characterization in general.

blog.name: silkygoldmilkweed
blog.title: sansa stark & sandor clegane are soulmates

tags: a song of ice and fire
summary: "A voice from nowhere," Sandor said. He peered through his helm, looking this way and that. "Spirits of the air!"
body:
“A voice from nowhere,” Sandor said. He peered through his helm, looking this way and that. “Spirits of the air!”

This foreshadowing of Sansa’s consciousness flying out of her body and into Sandor Clegane–like a little bird, you could say–appears in Tyrion’s first chapter in the very first book. (Tyrion, of course, is a character with family connections to Sansa and Sandor but he also has some “beast” aspects that parallel him to Sandor.)

In a later Catelyn chapter, Marillion the singer states, “The Starks know no music but the howling of wolves.“ Bran also talks about how the howling of wolves is a kind of song. Arya thinks that while she doesn’t recognize a certain song, her sister would certainly know it. Sandor asks for and later demands a song from Sansa.

Bird song. Wolf song. Love songs. A song of ice and fire.

Sansa is a warg. The Hound is her wolf.

It’s baked into the very first pages of the story.
